Description: The manuscript or edition where the example is found.

This contains a more precise locus. The information has various forms: folio column and gloss number (e.g. 023b04 =  folio 23¢ column b¢ gloss 4). The information can also be a citation of a standard edition¢ e.g Gwynn.1913.472.fol.179v1 or Thes.i.493.123. If the Source is found in POMIC (https://www.dias.ie/celt/celt-publications-2/celt-the-parsed-old-and-middle-irish-corpus-pomic/) then this column simply specifies that this is in POMIC. If the Source is an edition¢ this column gives the page number¢ and sometimes the line or verse number.

This contains a more precise locus. The information comes in variou sforms: an folio colum and gloss number to the one given in Locus 1 if any¢ or the POMIC sentence number if  the value of Locus 2 is “POMIC”¢ or the title of the text or manuscript (sometimes accompanied by a line number)¢ or the Journal abbreviation and volume number if the Source is an edition.
This contains the CorPH Sentence ID (https://chronhib.maynoothuniversity.ie/chronhibWebsite/home) or a link to a digital version of the text and page where the example is found.
The full sentence or gloss.
The translation of the full sentence or gloss
The subpart of the full sentence/gloss that contains a possible reflexive item. The immediate context is typically¢ but not exclusively¢ a clause.
The translation of the IMMEDIATE CONTEXT.
The constituent containing a possible reflexive item.
The translation of the MORPH column.
The analysis of the MORPH column.

This contains an analysis of the Function of the morph (subject¢ object¢ complement¢ predicate¢ cleft pivot¢ etc)¢ and the syntactic category in which the morph is embedded (noun phrase¢ verbal noun¢ prepositional phrase¢ etc.) or which immediately dominates the morph (e.g. PRON-¢ for infixed or suffixed pronouns).
The lemma of the verb in the IMMEDIATE CONTEXT if any.
The subject in the IMMEDIATE CONTEXT if any.
The analysis of the subject in the IMMEDIATE CONTEXT if any.
The subpart of the full sentence/gloss that governs the IMMEDIATE CONTEXT and contains potential coreference between two or more phrases.
This is the analysis of the type of governing context: cleft sentence¢ elision¢ or a governing clause headed by a verb
The lemma of the verb in the GOV CONTEXT.
The subject in the GOV CONTEXT if any.
The analysis of the subject in the GOV CONTEXT if any.
This shows the coreference between the Morph and the Clausal Subject¢ if any.
This shows the coreference betewen the Clausal Subject or the Governing Context subject and other constituents in the immediate context.
This is designates an example as either reflexive or not¢ or unclear.
Notes on the example.
